generalInfo:
This 8-day island-hopping journey across the Galapagos offers a front-row seat to one of the planet’s most extraordinary natural spectacles. From the volcanic highlands of Isabela to the iconic viewpoints of Bartolome and the wildlife-rich waters around North Seymour, this adventure brings you face to face with the raw beauty and biodiversity of the archipelago.

The trip begins on Isabela Island, where you’ll hike to the rim of Sierra Negra Volcano and snorkel among sea lions and reef sharks at Tintoreras Islet. Explore lava tunnels, crystal-clear coves, and spot blue-footed boobies and marine iguanas as you discover otherworldly landscapes shaped by fire and time. On Santa Cruz, you'll wander lava tubes and walk beside giant tortoises in the lush highlands before relaxing at Tortuga Bay’s striking beaches.

Sailing tours to nearby uninhabited islands—like Bartolome, North Seymour, Santa Fe, or Plazas—bring close encounters with unique Galapagos species and dramatic scenery. Every day offers chances to snorkel, hike, and explore, whether you're swimming alongside sea turtles or photographing surreal volcanic formations.

The tour ends with a visit to the Charles Darwin Research Station, where conservation comes to life. With expert guides, seamless transfers, and carefully curated excursions, this trip is perfect for travelers seeking a dynamic and immersive Galapagos experience.

dayInfo.description: (Quito / Guayaquil – Baltra – Puerto Ayora – Isabela) Begin with a flight from Quito or Guayaquil to Baltra’s airport. Upon arrival, a naturalist guide will transfer you to Puerto Ayora. After lunch in town, you will proceed to the port to embark on a public speedboat to Isabela Island (approximately 2 to 2.5 hours of navigation). A local contact will then take you to your hotel for check-in. The day concludes with a visit to the Flamingo Lagoon, followed by dinner and accommodation at your hotel. Note: For this itinerary, it is essential to select an early flight arriving at Baltra by maximum 10:00 AM. Meals: Lunch / Dinner

(Full Day Isabela) Around 7:30 AM, your private trip to Sierra Negra Volcano start. You will be transported for approximately 45 minutes to the Galapagos National Park control site. From there, you will begin a trek to the Sierra Negra and Chico Volcanoes, with a box lunch provided during the trek. In the afternoon, you will return to your hotel before preparing for a visit to Tintoreras Islet. You will embark on small speedboats from the Puerto Villamil dock. After a brief ride (approximately 20 minutes), you will arrive at Tintoreras. Following a hike across the islet, you will have the opportunity to snorkel. Underwater, you may encounter starfish, multicolored fish, sea urchins, and with luck, manta rays, sharks, and sea lions swimming very close to you. You will then return to Isabela for dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Half Day Isabela) Located 40 minutes from Puerto Villamil, your first visit site is Roca Union, where you can observe masked pikemen. You will then proceed to Los Tuneles (The Tunnels), a unique geological formation created by lava flow from the Sierra Negra volcano, resulting in natural arches, points, tubes, and tunnels both above and below water. At this site, you can enjoy a short 10-15 minute walk to observe the volcanic formations and various birds. Next, you will visit El Finado, a secluded cove with crystal-clear, calm waters, perfect for snorkeling among mangroves and swimming near sea turtles, reef fish, and resting sharks. A box lunch is included. You will then return to Isabela for a free afternoon, followed by dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Isabela – Santa Cruz) At 5:30 AM, you will be transferred to the port for a public speedboat to Santa Cruz (approximately 2 to 2.5 hours of navigation). Upon arrival, you will be transferred to your hotel for check-in and breakfast. Your guide will then pick you up for a trip to the highlands of Santa Cruz, where you will observe giant tortoises in their natural habitat. The Highlands of Santa Cruz are notably lush green, contrasting beautifully with the drier lower islands, with scalessia trees being the dominant vegetation. You will also explore lava tubes, extending over half a mile underground, offering a unique and surreal walking experience. After lunch in town, you will visit Tortuga Bay. This involves an approximate 45-minute walk along a cactus trail to Playa Brava, known for its strong currents and abundant marine iguanas, marine birds, and pelicans. Following Playa Brava, a 15-minute walk leads to Playa Mansa, a natural lagoon frequented by blue-footed boobies and pelicans, ideal for swimming and relaxation. You will then walk the same distance back to your hotel for dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Sailing Tours) On one of these days, you will visit either Bartolome or North Seymour or Plazas or Santa Fe Island. After breakfast, your guide will meet you in the hotel lobby to take you to the dock and commence the tour. Lunch will be provided onboard the small yacht. In the afternoon, you will return to the port. North Seymour Island is an excellent location for hiking, swimming, and snorkeling, with key attractions including frigates, boobies, gulls, hawks, green sea turtles, and Galapagos Sharks. Bartolome Island is celebrated for its iconic landscape, being the most photographed island in the Galapagos, offering spectacular views of two beautiful bays and fascinating lava formations and volcanic cones. Plazas Islands comprise two islands, where the turquoise waters of the channel beautifully contrast with the white sand and black lava coast. It is a prime spot for observing marine life, including manta rays, with coasts ideal for snorkeling. Santa Fe Island (also called Barrington Island), a small island of 24 square kilometers (9.3 sq mi) located in the center of the Galapagos archipelago, southeast of Santa Cruz Island. Geologically, it is one of the oldest, with volcanic rocks dating back approximately 4 million years. Its vegetation is characterized by brush, palo santo trees, and a large variety of the prickly pear cactus Opuntia echios. The chosen island for the sailing tour will depend on available spaces. You will then return to your hotel for dinner and accommodation. Meals: Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner

(Santa Cruz – Baltra) In the early morning, you will visit the Charles Darwin Station. Here, you will observe various species of Giant Tortoises and learn about ongoing conservation efforts aimed at preserving both the Giant Tortoises and the archipelago's environment. Afterwards, you and your guide will take the approximately 1-hour route to the airport. At the airport, you will board your flight back to Quito or Guayaquil. Meals: Breakfast
